prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
The winner of a Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, tournament has been stripped of his title after allegations of inappropriate behaviour.

Yan Chenglong has also been accused of cheating by using a communication device analogous to anal beads.

The 48-year-old has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it's impossible to prove accusations of cheating.

Xiangqi has been hugely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CXA, Mr Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament held on the Chinese island of Hainan last week.

He then defecated in the hotel bath in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CXA statement.

The CXA was forced to address rumours circulating online that Mr Yan had cheated using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Yan engaged in cheating via 'anal beads' as speculated on social media," the CXA said.

As punishment for bad behaviour, Mr Yan was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.
stories:
The title of "Xiangqi King" at a recent national tournament on Hainan Island, China, was taken away from Yan Chenglong due to reports of unacceptable conduct.

Following his victory, Yan was accused of using a communication device akin to anal beads for cheating.

As a result, Yan has been suspended from competing for a year and had his title revoked by the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA).

However, the CXA stated that they cannot definitively prove the cheating allegations.

Xiangqi, a centuries-old Chinese board game, has enjoyed great popularity across Asia.

According to the CXA, Yan was seen consuming alcohol with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the tournament. He later damaged hotel property and disregarded public order and decency by defecating in the bath.

Rumors spread online that Yan had cheated using anal beads fitted with wireless transmitters. The CXA acknowledged these rumors but expressed doubt that they could be substantiated.

As a consequence of his behavior, Yan has been deprived of his title and prohibited from participating in tournaments for a year. The CXA did not reveal the exact amount of prize money Yan would forfeit, but Xiangqi competitions typically award winners substantial sums of money, according to AFP.

At a recent national Xiangqi tournament on Hainan Island, China, Yan Chenglong's title as "Xiangqi King" was stripped away due to allegations of improper conduct.

Following his triumph in the competition, Yan was accused of employing a covert communication device resembling anal beads to gain an unfair advantage.

As a penalty, Yan was barred from competing for a year, and the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) revoked his title.

The CXA announced that they lack the definitive evidence to validate the cheating allegations.

Xiangqi, an ancient Chinese board game with a significant following in Asia, has recently come under scrutiny due to Yan's unacceptable behavior.

According to the CXA, Yan was spotted consuming alcohol with companions in his hotel room shortly after winning the tournament. Subsequently, he caused damage to the hotel property and breached public order and decency by defecating in the bathtub.

Rumors circulated online that Yan had cheated by using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters. The CXA acknowledged these rumors but expressed uncertainty about their veracity.

Due to his actions, Yan relinquished his title and was banned from participating in tournaments for a year. The CXA did not disclose the precise amount of prize money Yan would forfeit, but it is common knowledge that Xiangqi competitions reward winners with substantial sums of money, as reported by AFP.

After securing the top spot in the event, Yan was implicated in the use of a hidden communication device resembling anal beads to secure an unjust advantage.

As a consequence, Yan was prohibited from joining any competitions for a year, and the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) rescinded his title.

The CXA disclosed that they do not possess conclusive proof to substantiate the cheating accusations.
